p: Clinical myxomatosis frequently occurs in a subacute or chronic form, with severe productive rhinitis and dyspnea [ 5, 6]. Affected rabbits can have a rapid course to septicemia and death, or have pulmonary lesions, blepharitis, aural, and urogenital swelling, and cutaneous myxomas or, in subacute cases, bacterial superinfection [ 6, 7]. In terms of pathogenicity and virulence, the immune suppressing effect of some myxoma viruses [ 8] is of particular note.
